links.title: Things That Turbo Pascal is Smaller Than
links.description: Turbo Pascal 3 for MS-DOS was released in September 1986. Being version 3, there were lesser releases prior to it and flashier ones after, but 3 was a solid representation of the Turbo Pascal experience: a full Pascal compiler, including extensions that it made it practical for commercial use, tightly integrated with an editor. And the whole thing was lightning fast, orders of magnitude faster at building projects than Microsoft's compilers.

links.title: HORNET: High-speed Onion Routing at the Network Layer
links.description:
We present HORNET, a system that enables high-speed end-to-end anonymous
channels by leveraging next generation network architectures. HORNET is
designed as a low-latency onion routing system that operates at the network
layer thus enabling a wide range of applications. Our system uses only
symmetric cryptography for data forwarding yet requires no per-flow state on
intermediate nodes. This design enables HORNET nodes to process anonymous
traffic...
links.original_title: Hornet: High-Speed Onion Routing at the Network Layer

links.title: Breaking and (Partially) Fixing Provably Secure Onion Routing
links.description:
After several years of research on onion routing, Camenisch and Lysyanskaya,
in an attempt at rigorous analysis, defined an ideal functionality in the
universal composability model, together with properties that protocols have to
meet to achieve provable security. A whole family of systems based their
security proofs on this work. However, analyzing HORNET and Sphinx, two
instances from this family, we show that this proof strategy is broken. We
...

links.title: Natural image reconstruction from brain waves: a novel visual BCI system with native feedback
links.description: Here we hypothesize that observing the visual stimuli of different categories trigger distinct brain states that can be decoded from noninvasive EEG recordings. links.title: Type certificate - Wikipedia
links.description: A type certificate signifies the airworthiness of a particular category of aircraft, according to its manufacturing design (‘type’). It confirms that the aircraft is manufactured according to an approved design, and that the design ensures compliance with airworthiness requirements.

links.title: Ship of Theseus - Wikipedia
links.description: In the metaphysics of identity, the ship of Theseus is a thought experiment that raises the question of whether an object that has had all of its components replaced remains fundamentally the same object. The concept is one of the oldest in Western philosophy, having been discussed by the likes of Heraclitus and Plato by ca. 500-400 BC.

links.title: Betteridge's law of headlines - Wikipedia
links.description: Betteridge's law of headlines is an adage that states: "Any headline that ends in a question mark can be answered by the word no". It is named after Ian Betteridge, a British technology journalist who wrote about it in 2009, although the principle is much older.[1][2] As with similar "laws" (e.g., Murphy's law), it is intended to be humorous rather than the literal truth.[3][failed verification]
